review_title: Experience as a Starbucks Store Manager
pros:
*Work with fabulous employees and get the opportunity to inspire them day to day. 
*Great company values, highlighting what matters in the world, and genuinely making a difference in communities. Commitments to several organizations to give back. Neighborhood Grants, Donating all our food at end of day. Volunteer opportunities. Donation matching. Ect.
Great Benefits:
*20 free sessions per year with a therapist through for yourself. Family member gets their own 20 free sessions as well through this benefit. 
*Affiliation with Perks at Work, providing discounts to a wide spectrum of things. 
*Free Spotify Premium account
*30% food, beverage and merchandise at all times. Free drinks while working. Seven free food items per week. One free mark-out per week of coffee or tea. 
*401k with 5% company contribution. 
*Grants and gifted stocks = free money once grants are vested and sold. 
*Salaried employees get quarterly bonuses based on store success. 
*Salaried employees start off with 3 weeks vacation or more based on how many years tenure. 
*Paid maternity leave for 6 weeks. 
*Up to 30k in adoption cost reimbursement 
*Free bachelor's degree through ASU 
*Quickly accumulating family sick time based on average hours per week
*Flexible schedule - you're making the schedule
cons:
*Messaging lacks consistency week to week leaving management often in a tailspin of confusion. 
*A feeling of disconnect between corporate/upper management with the everyday happenings in stores.  
*Career progression farce. Hiring people from outside the company for higher management or corporate positions rather than supporting the growth and development of current employees. 
*Way behind in technology. Constant issues with tech that are debilitating to store functionality.
*Inconsistency with hired vendors to complete tasks in store. 
*Inconsistency with company policies store to store, district to district. 
*Baristas are not paid a living wage. Managers must hold employees to the highest caliber and standard while confronting the reality of the employees being unable to afford the cost of living. 
*Little to no opportunity for raises as a Store Manager. 
*Bonuses that are dependent on store success factored into your salary. 
*Paid maternity is only six weeks when comparable companies have up to 20 weeks- 12 weeks at least. 
*Leveling up issues either get late responses or not at all.
*No opportunities for further education if you already have degree 
*Labor cuts 
*The increasing culture of glorified fast food vs. a coffee experience

pros:
-Often comes with great coworkers happy to work as a team
-If you love coffee, well, you will be surrounded by it! You get daily markouts and discounts!
-Fast paced and on your feet so shifts tend to go by quickly and you get in a bit of exercise

Generally being a barista can be a good time if not a little tiring. I miss it every once in awhile.
cons:
-Stress! It can be a very stressful job, especially as a shift supervisor. If the person/people training you are not good at training, you will struggle to learn efficiently and meet expectations 
-Fast paced (but bad this time!) While it's nice to keep things moving, when you're running the shift it can be overwhelming with so much to do, I often found myself skipping my breaks in order to make sure everything got done and the baristas got their breaks on time.

Being a shift supervisor was not very rewarding to me, I found that no matter what I did it wasn't enough. To be fair, I had to work with a couple of nasty coworkers who were constantly demeaning (and perhaps a little predatory). It left me feeling burnt out and is why I ended up leaving the company in the end. But this will vary depending on the store, your experience will be different based on who your coworkers and managers are and how well your store functions.

pros:
Starbucks offers some great benefits like healthcare for part-time employees that make it an excellent option for those needing healthcare benefits on a part-time work basis.

It can be a fun place to work if you're in your teens or twenties. I did become friends with a lot of the employees since we were together a lot and bonded over our experiences at work.
cons: My experience at Starbucks started with mismanagement from the first opening of its doors. We had little to no training and were placed in a "sink or swim" environment with high store traffic. Our manager did not know what he was doing, and the lack of training & management on the floor caused an extremely high turnover rate. We were often understaffed and left to deal with angry customers. Starbucks as a company also takes the sides of its customers despite how horribly staff are treated by them (customers).

job_title: Shift Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: The company has great benefits, even for part-time employees, as well as fairly competitive pay for the industry. The hours can be somewhat flexible, but this has varied greatly under different managers I've worked for. In this role, you get a small insight into certain aspects of how businesses are run because there are opportunities to manage inventory, learn about safe cash handling, coaching and training, and auditory compliance (health inspector or third party audit.)
cons: This is a difficult job because of the stress level. Generally, you are in charge of a store in the absence of a store manager, and all the problems tend to fall in your direction. You have to juggle many tasks every day such as delegating and deploying partners (employees) in the most efficient manner, dealing with customer complaints, dealing with various security issues, tending to/calling in repairs, all while there is a relentless influx of customers. It is very difficult to do perfectly every time, although it is satisfying when accomplishing it. The other big con of this role is dealing with disciplinary issues. You may coach baristas if they are doing something wrong, but you may not issue any punitive measures. You get all of the responsibility of a manager, but none of the authority of a manager.

pros: The team was great. I liked my fellow Baristas. We all had a great time on shift.
cons: It opened way too early. Customers were addicted to their drink orders and would get angry at the slightest inconvenience. It was unpredictably busy. The lobby could get packed during Covid and no one seemed to care. Didn't feel like a human making people's drinks and food. The emphasis on "connecting" with people had the opposite effect. If I could even get the chance to talk to a customer, because it was so busy, it never felt like a genuine, organic connection. Some people you just don't want to talk to, some people you do.

pros:
- Good benefits even for part time
- Flexible positions that keep you from tiring from doing the exact same task day in and day out
- Good for outgoing types but there are still plenty of support and barring positions for those who are more introverted
- Other than lots of walking, some bending, and the occasional heavy (but almost never more than 20lbs) lifting, the physical work is VERY light and accommodations would be easy to make for most physical limitations, although as a workplace it is unfortunately not accessible to mobility aids other than canes
- *Can* be an excellent space for LGBTQ+ folks. Your mileage may vary as it ultimately depends on the store manager's direction and the attitudes of your coworkers, but the company itself at least attempts to be inclusive and considerate of the needs and identities of its workers
- Upward mobility is very possible, but it heavily depends on your store management (see my final "Cons" point)
cons:
- In most areas, not a livable wage unless you're working full time or as a shift supervisor
- Hours get cut for everyone nearing the end of the fiscal calendar (end of summer / start of fall) so rushes get more stressful and it becomes harder to make ends meet without a second income
- Constant on-your-feet busywork, can be great for some work styles (like mine) but if you're someone who needs to take breaks you may struggle
- The Starbucks brand relies on treating each customers as if they're special for patronizing the store. The stereotypes are true: there are a LOT of prissy customers that will throw temper tantrums over their orders, on top of the standard minimum wage worker harrassment. Come with thick skin as you're expected to baby each customer through their hissy fits while they order their extortion drinks
- Your store manager will make or break your experience. I have an excellent manager and honestly the best person I have ever worked under at any job, and she genuinely looks out for her employees' futures and well being and ensures that we are treated with due respect by both her and all other employees. However, I have heard from several coworkers that have transferred from other stores that they had to work under racists, predators, neglectful, and/or vengeful management that made the entire experience unbearable. If looking to apply, make sure you schedule your interview with the store manager if at all possible and pay good attention to how they treat you and their current employees throughout your interview as a bad manager is worth avoiding entirely.

pros:
Lots of little benefits such as free pounds of coffee every week and food and drinks every shift. 

When the district manager is good and their store managers are good, good partners (employees) tend to be hired. So if you're in a strong district, you'll likely enjoy your work more.

Starbucks has a pretty robust HR department and communication ability. If an employee has a complaint, their store and district managers will usually respond so that every little detail is ironed out. If you have a problematic team member, or you are having personal issues, you can usually get the help you need.

Starbucks has many opportunities for resume building. Many things like partner training, coffee tastings, store initiatives, donations, and many other programs can be framed to look really good on your resume, so take advantage of them! If there's any gap in your skills that you feel makes it hard to apply for a higher paying job, there is something you can do about it at Starbucks. You can spend 3 years there and just do what is required, or you can spend 6 months taking advantage of every opportunity and make twice what they offer. And if you love it so much, come back with more experience and get hired as a store manager or some other role in the company!
cons:
But the food and drinks aren't always the most nutritious items, and you may find yourself gaining weight from all the carbs, sugar, and processed fats. You will also probably spend money on eating lunch at nearby restaurants and fast food, which will also affect your health and your pocketbook.

If you're in a tough area, you may find your work less enjoyable. The quality of team members will go down, and you may find that your partners don't get the proper training and ignore quality guidelines more often. Store managers may only enforce the bare minimum of standards and mostly when a district manager is coming around. This can be frustrating if you believe in serving the highest quality food and drinks.

Some stores have issues with employees gaming the system. It really occurs on a case by case basis and no two situations are the same, but some employees are very good at knowing how to lodge complaints against team members and supervisors they don't like, and the company is forced to take them seriously because that's their duty. Thriving in such an environment means you must take responsibility for your own actions and not depend upon or trust that everything will be okay just because the truth is on your side. The best thing to do in a difficult store or district is make a long-term plan for how to use Starbucks to get you somewhere, and avoid conflict with problematic employees. Go with the flow, and target projects and activities to build your resume so that you can move on.

Trying to move up within the company is rather difficult on average. You need that special kind of personality that everyone likes for whatever reason, and you need luck with timing to be able to take advantage of an opening. If you really like Starbucks, you might consider finding opportunities elsewhere and then coming back when you have the skills and experience to land a manager or other corporate position.

review_title: Good for a short term solution
job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
* Good benefits for part time employees, including special/hard to find benefits like full college tuition and fertility assistance 
* Flexible scheduling 
* Free coffee 
* Relatively simple work
cons:
* Work is deceptively hard on your body. Over years, I developed multiple repetitive stress injuries that didn’t fully heal until I quit. 
* You’ll work with a lot of teens/very young adults. Lots of interpersonal drama, call-outs, and hungover coworkers. 
* Company overall is on the decline, and many long term costumers and partners are just … over it. You’ll feel that burnout from day one. 
* The SM controls the kind of experience you have. Working at one Starbucks can be entirely different from another. I’ve been at some stores that are so welcoming, fun, and friendly, I never wanted to leave. Others left me feeling drained and down within a few hours.

pros: Overall, I loved working at Starbucks. I felt there was a very positive work environment amongst my co-workers. It does depend on your specific store though, I was lucky and ended up getting along really well with management and all my co-workers. Starbucks also offers great benefits including insurance, free ground coffee, and free drinks/food during your shifts. Work life balance is another good quality about this job. Lastly, they are willing to accommodate with scheduling if you have other obligations for school or anything else.
cons: One downside is that if you are an opener, you will work very early mornings. I didn't mind getting up this early once I got used to it, but it's definitely an adjustment. Another downside is that many days you will be stressed, constantly running around trying to get tasks done or keep up with an overwhelming influx of orders. You will deal with impatient customers and some angry comments from customers as well.

review_title: really depends on the baristas you work with
pros: some shifts felt like i was barely working since i would be having so much fun making drinks, talking to cool or fun customers and hanging out with my barista friends! familiarizing yourself with the regulars and having such a generous partner discount were all great and opened the door to many other opportunities with the experience i've gained in my time working at starbucks :) if you're considering working at one, maybe go buy a coffee and sit at the cafe and observe how the baristas interact with each other before submitting an application just to see if you can envision yourself in that sort of atmosphere!
cons: some shifts i'd be just barely keeping it together and was one word away from having a full on panic attack depending on who i was in the bar with; it really depends who the other baristas are and how well you click with them/if there's any pre-existing drama among the staff because since everyone's so young it's easy to succumb to pressure or negativity when it's dwelled in instead of resolved. i had to quit for the sake of my mental health, as i'd started to wake up from panic attacks the morning of certain shifts, but i'm certain that if i simply started off at a different location this situation wouldn't have happened. especially since i was new, i felt like a scapegoat or a sponge to absorb everyone's frustrations and anger; i'd been cussed at, had things grabbed from my hands, been told to just not touch anything even when i knew what i was doing, and never felt as though i actually belonged there.

review_title: Good if you find the right store

The day to day can be grating and it becomes hard to stay motivated when the people who you are required to serve are demoralizing and corporate won't give the managers the resources they need to run the stores effectively.

review_title: If you like being treated like a number under the veil of "maintaining the third place", this is for you.
pros: Fast paced environment so shifts feel super fast, the benefits are obviously amazing and the store is usually generally very fun to work in with the right shift supervisors and correct staffing. Training is quick and you are guaranteed a decent schedule should they allocate workers correctly. Pretty easy to catch onto as long as you're dedicated and have a sense of urgency but you definitely have to work hard and remain consistent. If you slip up at this job it has the potential to make or break depending who you mess up in front of.
cons: As of 6/22 Fashion Square Mall is extremely understaffed, cut down hours and does not allow overtime. They pick favorites and I was let go because I was two minutes late regardless of the grace period, while a colleague of mine was able to leave home early because someone threw a quarter at her head. Baristas who don't show up for three weeks get a single written warning and remain on the schedule as "non-coverage" leaving a ghost to work for us on the weekdays and frequently the weekends simply because paperwork is "not able to be done" in order to find someone better suited to actually show up for the job. Lack of positive affirmation from the hire ups, we're constantly being told our numbers aren't good enough with minimal incentive except the $200 bonus you get for finding more people to work for the company and the increase in wages to literally survive living in the area. I hope they figure this out because I initially loved working here until it became toxic.

pros: I loved our team at Starbucks, everyone was friendly and helpful. My boss was amazing and hardly gave me any sluff when it came to scheduling (I worked another job and was in school). It really did feel like a family.
cons:
Customers can feel like they can treat you poorly. With a "customer is always right" mindset, this can be agitating. Then again, the main clientele are caffeine addicts who haven't gotten their fix yet. 
Also, I found myself frustrated with how corporate things were. If I didn't do one thing in the exact way I was trained by the training videos, I was confronted by a manager. Also, I had no self control to stop drinking caffeine and my tolerance was obsolete by the time I left.

pros: Friendly. Good drinks. Nice customers. Their underlying intentions are good.
cons: Inconsistent expectations and efforts to fulfill them. Double standards in policies, what to do and not do, what is acceptable and what's not changes on a dime. It is also a turbulent work environment, with lack of consistency among practices. There is a my way or the highway culture amongst store managers and other authority roles, as well as an internal power struggle across these roles, vying for dominance over running a shift. Company is facing lots of internal earthquakes with it current unionization stumbles and is responding in a degrading and hostile way. Management is overbearing and judgmental of its baristas, presumptive, quick to call critical thinking insubordination and immediately shutdown employees from saying anything at all. All signs indicate the early but well established stages of internal hemorrhaging of goodwill and retaliatory passive aggressive behavior. Often misrepresents and mischaracterizes efforts and typical realities of life and people to suit its preconceived ideas and refuses to listen to anything other than what it believes. Problems accepting things for what they are, people, situations, lots of repressed animosity toward customers over understandable desires.

cons: The work was tiring at first, especially during a rush. There’s a lot to remember and a lot to keep track of, but it gets easier with time.
